factoid: In April, Rostóv was on orderly duty.
Between seven and eight in the morning, after a sleepless night, Rostóv sent for embers.
Rostóv changed his rain-soaked underclothes.
Rostóv said his prayers.
Rostóv drank tea.
Rostóv got warm.
Rostóv tidied up the things on the table and in his own corner.
Rostóv's face was glowing from exposure to the wind.
Rostóv had nothing on but his shirt.
Rostóv lay down on his back, putting his arms under his head.
Rostóv was considering the probability of being promoted in a few days for his last reconnoitering expedition.
Rostóv was awaiting Denísov.
Denísov had gone out somewhere.
Rostóv wanted a talk with Denísov.
Rostóv heard Denísov shouting behind the hut.
Denísov was excited.
Rostóv moved to the window to see whom he was speaking to.
Rostóv saw the quartermaster, Topchéenko.
Denísov shouted, 'I ordered you not to let them eat that Máshka woot stuff!'
Denísov said, 'And I saw with my own eyes how Lazarchúk bought some from the fields.'
Denísov said he had given the order again and again.
The quartermaster answered, 'They don’t obey.'
Rostóv lay down again on his bed.
Rostóv thought, 'Let him fuss and bustle now, my job’s done and I’m lying down—capitally!'
Rostóv could hear Lavrúshka talking.
Lavrúshka was a sly, bold orderly of Denísov.
Lavrúshka was talking about loaded wagons, biscuits, and oxen he had seen when he had gone out for provisions.
Denísov’s voice was heard shouting farther and farther away.
Denísov shouted, 'Saddle! Second platoon!'
Rostóv wondered, 'Where are they off to now?'
Five minutes later, Denísov came into the hut.
Denísov climbed with muddy boots on the bed.
Denísov lit his pipe.
Denísov scattered his things about.
Denísov took his leaded whip.
Denísov buckled on his saber.
Denísov went out again.
Denísov answered vaguely and crossly that he had some business.
Denísov said, 'Let God and our great monarch judge me afterwards!'
Denísov went out, and Rostóv heard the hoofs of several horses splashing through the mud.
Rostóv did not even trouble to find out where Denísov had gone.
Rostóv fell asleep.
Rostóv did not leave the hut till toward evening.
Denísov had not yet returned.
The weather had cleared up.
Near the next hut, two officers and a cadet were playing sváyka, laughing as they threw missiles which buried themselves in the soft mud.
Rostóv joined them.
In the middle of the game, the officers saw some wagons approaching with fifteen hussars on their skinny horses behind them.
The wagons escorted by the hussars drew up to the picket ropes.
A crowd of hussars surrounded them.
Rostóv said, 'There now, Denísov has been worrying, and here are the provisions.'
The officers said, 'So they are!'
The officers said, 'Won’t the soldiers be glad!'
A little behind the hussars came Denísov, accompanied by two infantry officers with whom he was talking.
Rostóv went to meet them.
One of the officers, a short thin man, was very angry.
The officer said, 'I warn you, Captain.'
Denísov replied, 'Haven’t I told you I won’t give them up?'
The officer said, 'You will answer for it, Captain. It is mutiny—seizing the transport of one’s own army. Our men have had nothing to eat for two days.'
Denísov said, 'And mine have had nothing for two weeks.'
The infantry officer said, 'It is robbery! You’ll answer for it, sir!'
Denísov said, 'Now, what are you pestewing me for?'
Denísov lost his temper.
Denísov said, 'I shall answer for it and not you, and you’d better not buzz about here till you get hurt.'
Denísov shouted, 'Be off! Go!'
The little officer shouted, 'Very well, then!'
The little officer was undaunted and did not ride away.
The little officer said, 'If you are determined to rob, I’ll…'
Denísov said, 'Go to the devil! quick ma’ch, while you’re safe and sound!'
Denísov turned his horse on the officer.
The officer muttered, 'Very well, very well!'
The officer threatenedly turned his horse and trotted away, jolting in his saddle.
